Decrease 1.meaning: To reduce in intensity, amount, or severity. (also) To diminish or lessen over time.
To shorten a text without losing its essence. (also) To reduce or diminish.
To reduce in force, value, or intensity.
To reduce the value or quality of something.

Decrease 2.meaning: Lessening the severity or culpability of an offense.
To alleviate symptoms without curing the underlying cause. (also) To moderate or lessen the seriousness of something.
To decrease in size, extent, or degree.

Extraordinary.meaning: Deviating from the norm or standard. (also) Unusual or abnormal in behavior or structure.
Unusual or striking due to being foreign or unfamiliar.
Strange or unusual. (also) Belonging specifically to someone or something.
Showing advanced abilities or maturity at an unusually early age.

General 1.meaning: To regard with disgust or hatred.
Side by side and facing the same way. (also) Up to date with the latest information or developments.
To emphasize or make more noticeable.
Sharp and forthright in tone or manner. (also) Having a sour or bitter taste.
Relating to beauty or the appreciation of beauty.

General 2.meaning: Filled with shock, horror, or amazement.
To make someone feel isolated or estranged. (also) To transfer ownership or rights.
Referring indirectly or implicitly to something.
Unselfishly concerned for the well-being of others.
The quality of being open to more than one interpretation.

General 3.meaning: To improve or make something better.
Something that is out of place in terms of time or chronology.
Something that deviates from the standard or norm.
To precede in time. (also) To assign an earlier date to an event or document.

General 4.meaning: A direct opposite or contrast. (also) A rhetorical device that juxtaposes contrasting ideas in balanced phrases.
Lack of interest, enthusiasm, or concern.
A concise statement expressing a general truth or principle.
The highest point or climax. (also) The point in an orbit farthest from Earth.
To pacify or placate someone by acceding to their demands.

General 6.meaning: Highly ornate and extravagant in style.

General 7.meaning: Something that spoils or damages. (also) A plant disease.

General 8.meaning: To declare someone a saint. (also) To treat something as sacrosanct.

Distress or embarrassment at having failed.

Loud and insistent noise or outcry.

Corresponding in size, extent, or degree.

General 10.meaning: Self-satisfied and unaware of potential dangers.
Serving to complete or enhance something.

General 11.meaning: Familiar with and at ease in many cultures or countries.
To desire something belonging to another.

A scarcity or lack of something.

General 13.meaning: A division or contrast between two opposing ideas or concepts.

To disregard or dismiss. (also) A reduction in price.

Still in existence, especially of documents or artifacts.

Well-suited to the occasion or circumstances. (also) Pleasing and fortunate.

Likely to arouse resentment or anger in others.

Done without care or interest; routine.

The highest point or peak of something.

Something that comes before and indicates the approach of something else.

General 58.meaning: To forbid or prohibit something, especially by law.
To satisfy a desire or appetite to the fullest.

Abundance 1.meaning: To exist in large numbers or quantities. (also) To be rich or well-supplied with something.
Excessively patriotic or biased in favor of one's group.
Excessively high, especially in price or cost.

Abundance 2.meaning: To show excessive flattery or affection to gain favor.
Excessively concerned with details or cleanliness; hard to please.
Having a red or flushed complexion. (also) Excessively intricate or ornate in style.
Excessively talkative, especially about trivial matters.
Excessively sentimental to the point of being sickening.

Abundance 3.meaning: Excessively obedient or attentive to please others.
Producing much fruit, foliage, or offspring. (also) Producing abundant works or results.

Abundance 4.meaning: An excessive amount of something. (also) To overindulge or consume excessively.
Full of twists and turns. (also) Complex or excessively lengthy.
An excessive or overabundant amount of something.

To make suffering or a problem less severe.
Self-confidence or assurance, especially in a demanding situation.
To restrict or limit. (also) To draw a boundary around something.

Strictness 2.meaning: Native or restricted to a particular area or region.
Shocking or sensational, often in a negative way. (also) Vivid in color, creating a harsh or unnatural effect.
A shackle for the hands or feet; a restraint. (also) To restrain or restrict someone.

To stop or restrict the flow of something, especially blood.
Strict or severe in manner. (also) The rear part of a ship.
Strict or exacting, often referring to rules or requirements.

Strictness 4.meaning: To become less intense or severe. (also) To sink to a lower level or into the ground.
Meeting the necessary conditions or standards. (also) Limited or restricted in some way.

Likely to cause disagreement or argument.
To disagree or express a differing opinion.
Not in harmony or keeping with the surroundings or other aspects.

To revoke, cancel, or repeal a law, order, or agreement.

Deception 1.meaning: To leave hurriedly and secretly to avoid detection or arrest.
To give a false impression or contradict.
A false statement meant to harm someone's reputation.

Deception 2.meaning: Done secretly, often to conceal an illicit purpose.
To conceal or disguise. (also) A garment worn over clothes as a covering.
To conspire or cooperate secretly for a deceitful purpose.
Secret agreement or cooperation for a fraudulent or deceitful purpose.
Concealed or hidden; not openly displayed.

Deception 3.meaning: To expose the falseness of a belief or idea.
To conceal one's true motives or feelings.
To reveal or make known (something private or secret).
To deceive or trick. (also) A person who is easily deceived.
Based on a mistaken belief or false reasoning.

Deception 4.meaning: To pretend to have a feeling, state, or injury.
Attracting attention in a vulgar or flashy way; false allure.
Not well known or difficult to understand. (also) To conceal or make unclear.
Done or shown openly; not hidden or secret.
Extremely poor; poverty-stricken. (also) Stingy or unwilling to spend money.

Deception 5.meaning: To prove a statement or theory to be wrong or false.
Something false or fake. (also) To falsely present as genuine.
A false spoken statement that damages someone's reputation. (also) To make false and damaging statements about someone.

Deception 6.meaning: To free someone from a false belief or misconception.

Clarity 1.meaning: Keen insight or quickness in understanding and decision-making.
Fear or anxiety about something. (also) Understanding or grasp of a concept.
Able to express ideas clearly and effectively. (also) To pronounce or express distinctly.

Clarity 2.meaning: Difficult to find, achieve, or understand.
To clear from blame or guilt.
Stated clearly and leaving no room for confusion.

Clarity 3.meaning: Impossible to pass through or enter. (also) Impossible to understand.
Complicated and difficult to understand. (also) Engaged in or connected to an activity.

Clarity 4.meaning: Clear and easy to understand. (also) Having full mental clarity.
Clear or obvious to the eye or mind. (also) To show or demonstrate plainly.
To deliberately make something unclear or difficult to understand.
Not transparent; not allowing light to pass through. (also) Hard to understand or interpret.
Easily recognizable or obvious. (also) A legal right granted for an invention.

Cloudy or opaque, especially with suspended particles. (also) Confused or unclear.
To clear someone of blame or suspicion. (also) To justify or prove the validity of something.

Easy.meaning: Easy to approach, reach, or use. (also) Open and receptive to ideas or experiences.
To make someone feel uneasy or embarrassed.

Acceptance.meaning: To accept something reluctantly but without protest.
A person inclined to question or doubt accepted opinions.

The practice of vigorous action or involvement to achieve political or social goals.

Energy 2.meaning: Intensely enthusiastic or passionate. (also) Heated or burning in literal or figurative terms.
Fast-paced and energetic in an uncontrolled way.

Energy 3.meaning: Sharp or highly developed (as in senses or intellect). (also) Eager or enthusiastic.
To express sorrow or regret. (also) A passionate expression of grief.
Intrusively enthusiastic in offering help or advice.
Eager or quick to argue, quarrel, or fight.
Vigorous or incisive in expression or style.

Anger 1.meaning: Angry and bitter, especially in speech or debate.
To discourage or prevent an action.
To strongly encourage or urge someone to do something.

Anger 2.meaning: Courage in facing pain or adversity.
Irritable and quarrelsome. (also) Difficult to control; unruly.
A lengthy and aggressive speech. (also) To lecture someone in a critical manner.

Anger 3.meaning: A person who is indifferent or hostile to culture and the arts.
To make someone less angry or hostile.
Showing determined courage in the face of difficulties.

Anger 4.meaning: A long, angry speech of criticism or accusation.
Aggressively defiant or eager to argue.
Extremely harmful or poisonous. (also) Bitterly hostile or antagonistic.

Skill.meaning: An expert with refined taste in a particular field.
A non-expert or someone not belonging to a particular profession.

Criticism 1.meaning: To warn or reprimand someone firmly. (also) To advise or urge earnestly.
To attack violently or criticize strongly.

Criticism 2.meaning: A bitter and prolonged verbal attack or criticism.

Attacking or challenging cherished beliefs or institutions.
To publicly criticize or ridicule using satire.
To imitate someone or something, often to entertain or ridicule. (also) To closely resemble something.

Criticism 4.meaning: Using humor, irony, or ridicule to criticize or expose.
To belittle or speak of someone or something in a disrespectful way.

Intelligence 1.meaning: Skillful and clever, especially with the hands or mind.

Clever or skillful in achieving a goal. (also) Deceptive or cunning.
Shrewd and careful, especially in business.

A young bird just learning to fly. (also) A person or organization that is inexperienced or new.
To give knowledge or information. (also) To influence or shape something.

Intelligence 3.meaning: Having knowledge of events before they take place.
Little known or obscure, often referring to complex or specialized knowledge.
Intended to correct or improve something, especially a skill or knowledge deficit.
Having keen judgment or insight; wise.

Intelligence 4.meaning: Delicate or understated, not immediately obvious. (also) Crafty or clever in approach.

Praise 2.meaning: To publicly promote or praise something.

Friendly 1.meaning: Friendly, easy to talk to, and approachable.
To make an unpleasant feeling less intense.
Relating to the pleasant aspects of the countryside.

A mild or indirect expression used in place of one that is harsh or unpleasant.
Sociable and enjoying the company of others.

Friendly 3.meaning: To lose vitality; to become weak or feeble. (also) To suffer in an unpleasant situation.

Health-giving or beneficial. (also) Pleasant or agreeable in climate or surroundings.

To expel or send away, typically as a punishment.
Mutual trust and friendship among people.

The disintegration or breaking apart of something. (also) The formal ending of a legal entity, such as a marriage or corporation.

Ending 3.meaning: Harmless or not likely to offend.
A natural tendency or inclination to behave in a certain way.
To reject or void something, especially a legal decision. (also) To suppress or put an end to something.

An unintended consequence of an event or action, especially an unwelcome one.

A person who spends money extravagantly.

Very weak or slight. (also) Thin or slender in form.

A gradual increase in intensity or volume.

Increase 2.meaning: To expand or swell due to pressure from within.
To increase rapidly in extent or intensity.
Capable of producing an abundance of offspring or growth; fertile. (also) Intellectually productive or creative.
To increase rapidly in numbers or spread quickly.

Silent.meaning: Distant and reserved in manner or behavior. (also) Physically distant or apart.
Unable to keep still or silent due to impatience or dissatisfaction.
Reserved or reluctant to share thoughts or feelings.
Reserved or uncommunicative in speech; saying little.

Emotion 1.meaning: Having mixed feelings or contradictory ideas about something or someone.
Intellectual rather than emotional or physical.
A feeling of boredom or listlessness due to lack of interest.

Emotion 2.meaning: To bring a feeling, memory, or image to mind.
Feeling or showing anger at what is perceived as unfair treatment.
Feeling or showing regret for wrongdoing.
Very deep, intellectually or emotionally. (also) Having a far-reaching impact.
A feeling of unease or doubt, often about one's own actions.

Emotion 3.meaning: Expressing opinions or feelings loudly and forcefully.
Feeling or showing caution about possible dangers or problems.
Feeling tired or worn out. (also) Bored or impatient with something tedious.
Having or showing great passion or enthusiasm.
Not showing or feeling emotion; expressionless.

Flexibility 1.meaning: Open to suggestion or willing to comply.
Willing to obey rules or conform to requests.
Unwilling or unable to believe something; skeptical.
Unwilling to compromise or change one's views.
Stingy or unwilling to spend money.

Flexibility 2.meaning: Easily bent or flexible. (also) Easily influenced or yielding to others.
Having many curves and turns. (also) Flexible or graceful in movement.
Excessively willing to obey or serve others. (also) Less important; subordinate.
Willing to please others; obliging or agreeable.

Change 1.meaning: To make changes to a document or text to improve it. (also) To modify or revise something.
A sudden, unpredictable change in mood or behavior.
Firmly established and unlikely to change.
Likely to change opinions or loyalties frequently.
Interchangeable and replaceable by another identical item.

Change 2.meaning: Prone to sudden changes in mood or behavior.
Relating to or affecting the fundamental nature of something; far-reaching. (also) Advocating for thorough or complete political or social change.
Prone to rapid and unpredictable changes, especially for the worse. (also) Easily evaporated at normal temperatures (used for chemicals).

Disagreement 1.meaning: Characterized by friendliness and a lack of conflict.
To struggle or compete for something. (also) To assert a position in an argument.
Relating to or causing internal conflict or dissent.
Designed to cause fires. (also) Likely to provoke anger or conflict.

A noisy dispute or quarrel. (also) A series of objects arranged in a line.
To defeat thoroughly in a conflict or contest.

Scarcity 1.meaning: Lacking a definite form or clear structure.
Lacking moral principles; ignoble. (also) The lowest part or foundation of something.
Lacking a clear plan or purpose.

Scarcity 2.meaning: Spread out over a large area. (also) Lacking clarity or focus; verbose.
Lacking initiative or strength of character; ineffective.
Lacking physical strength, often due to age or illness. (also) Lacking strength of character or effectiveness.
Lacking social grace or sophistication; awkward.

Scarcity 3.meaning: Narrow-minded or not open to new ideas. (also) Lacking generosity.
Just begun and not fully formed or developed; rudimentary. (also) Lacking structure or organization.

Scarcity 4.meaning: Lacking in quantity or quality; insufficient.
Ordinary or lacking excitement; everyday. (also) Of the earthly world rather than a spiritual one.
Short-sighted, either literally or figuratively (lacking foresight or imagination).
A person walking along a road or street. (also) Lacking inspiration or excitement; dull.

Scarcity 5.meaning: Nervous or easily frightened. (also) Lacking stability; unpredictable.
Lukewarm in temperature. (also) Lacking enthusiasm or interest.
Overused and lacking originality or freshness.

Scarcity 6.meaning: Lacking education, refinement, or sophistication. (also) Not prepared for growing crops.
Lacking or deficient in a quality or necessary component.
Lacking harmony; clashing or conflicting. (also) Disagreeing or incongruous.

Confidence.meaning: Comparable in certain respects, typically to clarify.
Confidently self-assured in stating opinions or demands.
Open to more than one interpretation; ambiguous. (also) Uncertain or questionable in nature.

Temporary 1.meaning: A short, amusing, or interesting story about a real incident or person.
A temporary departure from the main subject in speech or writing.
Lasting for a very short time.
Lasting for a very short time.

Temporary 2.meaning: A short, confused fight or struggle. (also) To move in a hurried or awkward manner.
Brief and to the point; concise.
Lasting only for a short time; temporary. (also) A person staying in a place for a short time.

Ordinary 1.meaning: To smear or rub with oil, typically as part of a religious ceremony. (also) To choose or designate someone for a role or position.
A typical example or original model of something.
Contrary to common sense or expectation.
A typical example or pattern of something; a model.

Power 1.meaning: A strong feeling of dislike or aversion.
A formal or authoritative statement or pronouncement.
Not influenced by strong emotion; impartial and rational.

Power 2.meaning: Commanding and authoritative. (also) Relating to or characteristic of a magistrate.
Having a strong spiritual or divine quality.
A strong liking or inclination for something.
Evoking a strong emotional reaction, especially sadness or regret.

Power 3.meaning: Relating to or involving strongly critical or controversial speech or writing.
A strong preference or special liking for something.
A strong feeling that something is about to happen, especially something bad.
Causing a strong reaction, especially deliberately.
Loyal, reliable, and hardworking. (also) Strongly built or sturdy.

Power 4.meaning: Characterized by strong and turbulent emotions. (also) Relating to or resembling a storm.
Having a strong, sharp taste or smell. (also) Sharply expressive or critical.

Support 1.meaning: A person who defends or supports something controversial.
To support or defend a cause.
To confirm or support with evidence.

Support 2.meaning: Facial expression. (also) To support or tolerate.
A strong supporter of a party, cause, or person. (also) Prejudiced in favor of a particular cause.
The use of someone or something for help or protection.
To seek the favor, affection, or support of someone.

Relevant 1.meaning: Highly appropriate or relevant to the situation.
Irrelevant or unrelated to the current topic. (also) Coming from the outside.
Treating serious issues with deliberately inappropriate humor.
Relevant to the subject at hand.
Relevant or applicable to a particular matter.

Obscurity.meaning: Known or understood by only a few; mysterious or obscure.
To surpass or overshadow. (also) An astronomical event where one celestial body obscures another.

Old 1.meaning: Old-fashioned or outdated. (also) Relating to an earlier historical period.
To captivate or hold someone's attention completely.
Holding beliefs that differ from the accepted norm or tradition.
Easily shaped or molded (literally or metaphorically).
Motivated by money or material gain rather than ethics. (also) A professional soldier hired to serve in a foreign army.

Old 2.meaning: Holding firmly to an opinion or course of action.
Able to be molded or shaped. (also) Artificial or superficial in nature.

Hard 1.meaning: Involving or requiring a lot of effort; difficult and tiring.
A confusing and difficult problem or question.
Clumsy or difficult to handle due to size or weight.
Hard to control or deal with.

Hard 2.meaning: A solution or remedy for all difficulties or diseases.
A state of perplexity or uncertainty over what to do in a difficult situation.
Able to recover quickly from difficulty or adversity. (also) Capable of returning to its original shape after being bent or stretched.
To overcome a difficulty or obstacle. (also) To be placed on top of something.
Sensitivity and skill in dealing with others or with difficult issues.

Hard 3.meaning: Offering nothing stimulating or challenging; dull.
Keeping careful watch for potential danger or difficulties.

Honesty 1.meaning: Without guile or deceit; natural and sincere. (also) Lacking skill or refinement.
The quality of being frank and sincere.
Fluent but insincere or shallow in speech.

Honesty 2.meaning: Strong moral principles; honesty and integrity.
The art of effective or persuasive speaking or writing. (also) Language that is insincere or empty in substance.

Honesty 3.meaning: Used as an intensifier, often to qualify a metaphor; true or genuine.
Free of deceit or cunning; innocent and sincere.

Attention 1.meaning: Showing great care, attention, and effort.
Cautious and careful to consider all circumstances.
Evoking interest or attention. (also) Forceful or persuasive.
Done quickly and without attention to detail.
Careful and circumspect in speech or actions to avoid offense or attention.

Attention 2.meaning: Very attentive to detail and cleanliness.
Attempting to avoid notice or attention, often because of guilt.
To pay attention to or take notice of.
Done at random or without careful judgment.

Attention 3.meaning: Failing to take proper care or attention.
Designed to impress or attract attention, often in a showy manner.
To cause something to happen suddenly or unexpectedly. (also) Acting hastily or without careful consideration.
Dangerously steep or high. (also) Done suddenly and without careful thought.
Diligent and extremely attentive to detail. (also) Very concerned to avoid doing wrong.

Courage 1.meaning: Bold and daring, often recklessly so. (also) Showing a lack of respect.
A show of boldness intended to impress or intimidate.
Attracting attention through exuberance or bold style.

Helpful.meaning: Favorable or indicative of good fortune.
Happening at a favorable time; opportune. (also) Involving divine foresight or intervention.
Not favorable or likely to succeed.
To suggest or hint at something subtly, often negative. (also) To maneuver oneself into a favorable position.

Simple.meaning: Severely plain or simple in style. (also) Strict or harsh in manner. Tertiary: Practicing self-discipline or abstention.
To interpret or explain the meaning of something.
To explain or analyze in detail.
A basic or essential item or commodity.

Physical.meaning: Extreme greed for wealth or material gain.
A state of physical or mental weariness; lack of energy.
Able to be touched or felt. (also) So intense as to seem almost tangible.
A state of physical or mental inactivity; lethargy.

Opposition 1.meaning: To turn away or prevent something from happening.
To surrender or give up resistance.
A person who opposes official policy or authority.
To prevent something from succeeding. (also) A character or element that contrasts another to highlight certain qualities.
To prevent or obstruct something by taking advance action.

Opposition 2.meaning: To obstruct or impede the progress of something.
To hinder or prevent an action or process.

Opposition 3.meaning: To remove or prevent the need for something.
A split or division between strongly opposed groups, often due to differing beliefs.
Relating to worldly as opposed to spiritual matters. (also) Relating to time.

Happiness.meaning: Cheerful and carefree. (also) Showing a casual indifference.
Able to float. (also) Cheerful and optimistic.

Arrogance 1.meaning: Overblown or pompous in speech or writing.
Asserting opinions in an authoritative or arrogant manner without evidence.
Believing in or advocating for the superiority of an elite class or group.

Arrogance 2.meaning: To treat with apparent kindness that betrays a sense of superiority. (also) To support or sponsor something.
Ominous or foreboding. (also) Pompous or self-important.
Overstepping boundaries of propriety or courtesy; arrogant.
Making a show of being morally superior to others.

Arrogance 3.meaning: Swollen or distended. (also) Overly complex or pompous in style.

Show 1.meaning: To wave or display something in a threatening or excited manner.
To restrain or control. (also) To show anger or resentment.
To raise objections or show reluctance.
Not showing care for consequences; rash.
Persisting tirelessly; showing no signs of fatigue.

Show 2.meaning: Having or showing good judgment or sense.
Having or showing a desire to cause harm to others.
Incomplete or not whole. (also) Showing bias or favor toward something.
Attempting to impress by showing greater importance, talent, or culture than is actually possessed.

Show 3.meaning: Showing concern or care for someone's well-being.
Showing nervousness or a lack of confidence.

Complex.meaning: Highly complex or intricate. (also) Relating to the Byzantine Empire.
A consequence of an action or event, especially when complex or unwelcome.

Persuasion.meaning: To persuade through flattery or coaxing.
Absolutely necessary or required. (also) Expressing a command or urgent request.
To persuade someone through deception or flattery.

Foolishness.meaning: Absurd or ridiculous to the point of being laughable.
Silly or foolish, especially in an unconscious or complacent way.

Restraint.meaning: To refrain from something; exercise self-control.
Relating to a parish or church. (also) Narrow-minded or limited in scope.
Moderate or restrained, especially in eating and drinking. (also) Characterized by self-discipline or avoidance of excess.

Unity.meaning: To come together to form one whole.

Certainty.meaning: The practice of forcing someone to act through threats or pressure.
To cause something to continue indefinitely.
To lose or cause to lose luster, especially from exposure to air or moisture. (also) To damage someone's reputation.

Moral 1.meaning: To overlook or accept behavior that is morally questionable.
To instruct or improve morally or intellectually.
Convenient and practical, although possibly improper or immoral.
A person who behaves without moral principles, especially in sexual matters. (also) A freethinker, especially in religious contexts.

Moral 2.meaning: A remark or statement, especially one with moral content, that is overused and unoriginal.
An unprincipled or immoral person. (also) Expressing disapproval.
Involving immoral or dishonorable actions. (also) Dirty or squalid.
Conformity to accepted standards of behavior or morals.

Harmful 1.meaning: A large and destructive fire. (also) A violent conflict or war.
Proceeding in a gradual, subtle way, but with harmful effects.
To speak harmful lies about someone. (also) Evil in nature or effect.

Harmful 2.meaning: To make something less severe, harmful, or painful.
Having a harmful effect, often in a subtle or gradual way.
To commit or carry out (a crime or harmful act).
Spreading unchecked, often in a harmful way.

Disrespect.meaning: Contempt or disdain toward someone or something considered unworthy. (also) To reject or refuse with contempt.
To reject with disdain or contempt.

Weakness.meaning: To weaken or drain energy from.
To weaken or damage, especially gradually or subtly.

Humility.meaning: Respectful submission to the authority or judgment of another.

Respect 1.meaning: Showing a lack of respect for things generally taken seriously.
A gesture of respect or deference, such as a bow.
Formidable, especially as an opponent. (also) Worthy of respect or honor.

Respect 2.meaning: To regard with great respect or reverence.

Dissuasion.meaning: To transfer power or responsibility. (also) To degenerate or deteriorate.
Determination to achieve something. (also) To settle or find a solution to a problem.

Slowness.meaning: To deliberately avoid or abstain from something.
Slow-moving and unexciting. (also) Working persistently but without enthusiasm.

Emotionless.meaning: Impartial or unbiased. (also) Not interested or indifferent.

Necessity.meaning: Essentially different in kind; not comparable.
To extract the essential meaning or most important aspects. (also) To purify a liquid through evaporation and condensation.
To discard or abandon something unnecessary. (also) To throw goods overboard to lighten a ship or aircraft.
Existing as a natural or essential quality of something.

Stubbornness 1.meaning: Rigidly devoted to theories or doctrines without regard for practicality.
Stubborn and determined to do as one pleases.
Unwilling to change due to rigid or conservative beliefs.
Stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or course of action.
Stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or behavior.

Stubbornness 2.meaning: To become rigid or inflexible. (also) To turn into bone.
Unwilling to change one's views or agree to compromise.
Stubbornly uncooperative or defiant of authority.

Laziness.meaning: Inactive or in a state of rest.
Land left unplanted to restore fertility. (also) Inactive or unproductive.
Lazy or avoiding activity. (also) Causing little or no pain (used medically).

Difference.meaning: Selecting ideas or styles from a diverse range of sources.
A work that imitates the style of previous works. (also) A mixture of different elements.
A completely different line of thought or action. (also) A straight line that touches a curve but does not cross it.
To waver between different opinions or actions.

Beauty.meaning: To decorate or add details to make something more attractive. (also) To exaggerate or add fictitious details.
Visually attractive, especially in a quaint or charming way.

Calm 1.meaning: Calmness and composure, especially in difficult situations.
Composed of diverse and different elements.
Composed of parts that are the same or similar.

Calm 2.meaning: A temporary calm or pause in activity. (also) To soothe or send to sleep.
Calm and peaceful, with little movement or activity.

Calm 3.meaning: Calm and dependable, showing little emotion or animation.
To moderate or soften something. (also) A state of mind, especially regarding anger or calmness.

Truth 1.meaning: To make something legally null and void; invalidate. (also) To cancel out or neutralize.

Truth 2.meaning: Showing great attention to detail or correct behavior.
To reject or disown something as untrue or unjust.
The appearance of being true or real.

Speed.meaning: Acting quickly and without thought; rash.

Forgiveness.meaning: To absolve someone from blame or responsibility.

Immoral.meaning: To drive out evil spirits. (also) To remove something undesirable.

Disorder.meaning: Confused or unsure how to respond. Secondary (informal, U.S.): Unfazed or unaffected.
Messy or dirty. (also) Careless or negligent.

Clumsiness.meaning: Slow and clumsy due to great weight. (also) Dull or laborious.

Unfriendly.meaning: A physical reaction where skin becomes bumpy due to cold or emotion.
Rude or disrespectful. (also) Irrelevant to the matter at hand.
Showing a rude or arrogant lack of respect.

Freedom.meaning: Unnecessary or uncalled for. (also) Free of charge.

Beginning.meaning: A messenger bringing important news. (also) To announce or signal the arrival of something.
Just coming into existence and beginning to display potential.
A beginner or someone new to a subject or activity.
New or original. (also) A long work of fiction.
In its original condition; unspoiled. (also) Clean and fresh as if new.

Permanent.meaning: Unchanging over time or unable to be changed.
Lasting for a long time or recurring repeatedly. (also) A plant that lives for more than two years.
Enduring pain or hardship without showing emotion.

Poverty.meaning: Having little or no money; poor.

Blame.meaning: To formally accuse or charge with a crime.

Unchanging.meaning: Not securely held or in position; dangerously unstable.

Similarity.meaning: Similar in nature or character; related. (also) One's family or relatives.

Generosity.meaning: Generosity in giving gifts or money.
Generous or forgiving, especially toward a rival or less powerful person.
Wastefully extravagant. (also) Having or giving something on a lavish scale.

Talkative.meaning: Using more words than necessary; wordy.

Sadness.meaning: A mournful poem or piece of music, often lamenting the dead.

Stinginess.meaning: Economical or frugal. (also) Restrained or limited in quantity.
A fixed period of time spent doing a specific activity. (also) To be frugal or limit resources.

Division.meaning: To divide into sharply opposing factions or groups.
To cut off or separate. (also) To break a connection or relationship.

Uncertainty.meaning: To avoid telling the truth by being evasive or ambiguous.

Unnecessary.meaning: Not or no longer needed or useful; superfluous.

Inclusion.meaning: To include or absorb something into a larger group or category.
